docs.snippet: Professional sports leagues that back the prohibition of betting on their games often tiptoe around their own opposition, but not all leagues have voiced a willingness to go as far as N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver....
docs.lead_paragraph: Professional sports leagues that back the prohibition of betting on their games often tiptoe around their own opposition, but not all leagues have voiced a willingness to go as far as N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver.
docs.abstract: NBA Commissioner Adam Silver becomes first chief of a major American sports league to call for federal sports betting laws to be changed so that states can allow betting on games; shift could represent major new income source for the NBA; other sports leagues, including the NFL, stand firm in their defense of the Professional and Amateur Sports Protection Act, which bans sports betting in all but a few instances.

headline.main: Will Other Leagues Join N.B.A.? Don’t Bet on It
headline.print_headline: Will Other Leagues Join N.B.A.? Don’t Bet on It

docs.snippet: A reporter went to Prospect Park seeking to measure the speed of anything that moved, from footballs to sea lions....
docs.lead_paragraph: A reporter went to Prospect Park seeking to measure the speed of anything that moved, from footballs to sea lions.
docs.abstract: New York Times reporter Andy Newman tests a radar gun, similar to those used by police to measure speeding vehicles, in Brooklyn's Prospect Park; outing proves what any traffic-ticket lawyer would say--there are many factors that can affect accuracy of radar technology.

headline.main: Speed Gun in Hand, Everything’s a Target
headline.print_headline: Our Radar’s Aim Was True. The Results, Not So Much.

docs.snippet: MALFETTI--James L., Sr. Professor Emeritus James L. Malfetti, a teacher for 43 years at Columbia College and Teachers College, Columbia University, died a year ago at his home in Carefree, AZ., at 92. The pioneer in sex education and traffic safet...
docs.lead_paragraph:
MALFETTI--James L., Sr.

Professor Emeritus James L. Malfetti, a teacher for 43 years at Columbia College and Teachers College, Columbia University, died a year ago at his home in Carefree, AZ., at 92. The pioneer in sex education and traffic safety research was a born leader and teacher, whose students flourished because he made them feel valued. Remembered as a man who genuinely liked people of all kinds, Professor Malfetti was beloved for his generosity, fairness, optimism and sense of humor. "Reproduction, Sex and Preparation for Marriage," which he co-authored in 1964, was a groundbreaking sex-education text published in at least five countries. In his 1957 "Electronic Controls and Traffic Safety," he envisioned self-driving cars. Adaptations of his 1970 "DWI Phoenix" program are still in use globally. Professor Malfetti was born in 1920 in College Point, NY, to Vincent and Annie Burns Malfetti. He grew up in New York City, where in his youth he was a Bronx Home News paperboy, baseball park ice cream hawker, bouncer, maitre'd, lifeguard and Fuller Brush man, among numerous other jobs. In WWII, he was Navy officer in the European and Asian theaters. He went to college on the GI Bill, earned his doctorate, taught human sexuality and transportation safety and served on committees of the Transportation Research Board, National Research Council and National Academy of Sciences. The AAA Foundation, government and numerous corporations funded his research and publications at Columbia, where he was Assistant to the Dean of Columbia College, Associate Director of the Bicentennial of Columbia University and Associate Director of the American Assembly, a body of prominent thinkers founded by President Eisenhower to address national problems. Professor Malfetti was a widely admired educator, speaker, administrator and lover of art and literature, who in his 90s, recited Shakespeare sonnets and Housman poems by heart -a storyteller's storyteller who enlightened and entertained generations of students, his family and all those fortunate enough to have known him. He is deeply missed.

docs.snippet: Investors are misled by overconfidence, inability to focus on long-term goals amid distractions, and distrust of professional advisers, a study found....
docs.lead_paragraph: Investors are misled by overconfidence, inability to focus on long-term goals amid distractions, and distrust of professional advisers, a study found.
docs.abstract: Paul Sullivan Wealth Matters column cites study by State Street's Center for Applied Research that finds investors are often misled by overconfidence, inability to focus on long-term goals amid distractions and distrust of professional advisers.

headline.main: The Folklore of Finance: Beliefs That Contribute to Investors’ Failure
headline.print_headline: The Folklore of Finance: Beliefs That Contribute to Investors’ Failure
